BOB WHITE: --going to have a
conversation about the case method of teaching. That is a primary way we
teach here at the school.

We'll be together for about 45
minutes in this live session. And we welcome you to
ask us any questions,

and we'll try to get
to those questions throughout our discussion. But before we dive in, let
me just tell you a little bit

about who I am. My name is Bob White. I graduated from here
many, many years ago.

I had a career in
finance, and then did a little bit of
presidential politics before joining the faculty
full time about five years ago.

I teach two courses. I teach one in our
first year curriculum called Field Global
Immersion, where

I go with a group of students
to a foreign country, where they haven't been before,
to work on some design thinking

process with global clients. And I also teach
Entrepreneurial Finance,

which is an elective course
in our second year curriculum. With me are three
about-to-be graduates.

You are going to-- it's going
to work out OK-- second year students who are
going to join us in this discussion, the
actually stars of the show.

So let me allow you to
introduce yourselves. SPEAKER 1: Hi, everyone. I am [INAUDIBLE]. I grew up all over the world.

But Atlanta, Georgia
is home right now. And I was in consulting
before coming to HBS.

BOB WHITE: Thank you. Thanks for coming. ISABEL KELLER: Hi, everyone. I'm Isabel Keller. I grew up in the
suburbs of New York City

and then lived in New York City
before coming to school here. And before school,
I was at LinkedIn.

OLLIE EVANS: Hi, everyone. My name is Ollie Evans. I'm from the suburbs
of Detroit, Michigan. And before school,
I was an investor.

BOB WHITE: Great. OK. So before we dive in
to what it's all about, I thought what made
sense is for us all

to be sure we know we're
talking the same language and describe actually
what a case study is. So this is a case study.

Typically it is written,
but oftentimes now we're doing more in multimedia
and videos, that

describes an actual
situation, something that's actually happened, where
a decision needs to be made.

And the protagonist, the key
person in the case, again, has to make a decision with
some uncertain information.

So the case, we put as much
information as possible. Sometimes we put in
data that's relevant. Sometimes we put in data
that's not relevant.

And that's part of
the potential problem. But hopefully you can
sort through the data and then come to a conclusion.

And that's something,
again, it's documented in each of our cases. The case could be about
a large corporation,

could be about a nonprofit,
could be about a startup company, right, could be
about a social enterprise, all of which, again, key
decisions need to be made.

And that's what gets
documented in these cases. And again, we're doing more
of these by multimedia. I've been involved in
several multimedia cases.

That's the case method. And the students
prepare the case. And we'll talk a little bit more
about what you all do to that.

And we as faculty also
prepare for the class. And we talk about that
a little later, too. But then we get
into the classroom.

And the classroom discussion
revolving around a case is basically 90 minutes-- I'm sorry, 80 minutes
for each session.

And it's where we
have the student becomes the decision maker. So you, as a student, take the
position of the protagonist,

having to make the decision
that's posed in the case. We ask students
to be articulate,

to articulate the
decision and why. And then it's a very dynamic,
really interesting interaction

where we have students
agree, disagree. We have to defend your position.

We ask questions to
make sure that we get down to probing
what was underlying that set of questions. And out of that,
hopefully you get

to analyze a lot of the issues. Hopefully you learn to
communicate effectively. Hopefully you learned to
disagree agreeably and join

on other people's points,
then hopefully build on those. And it's a incredible
dynamic that

goes on in our classrooms
around, again, the case study. And we believe that all
of what I just described

is the best way
to teach leaders, to teach the skills that
become great leaders. In almost every class, I
want to say, it was probably

60% of the classes,
at least in my course, we also have the
protagonist, the person who's in the case come.

And it's really interesting. Because they sit for 70
minutes listening to 90 experts

talk about the situation. And then they react
to that, right, and they tell us what
it was really like,

what some of the concerns really
were, and it brings to life. So that preparing the case,
having these interactions,

making points,
defending the points, and then having the
person actually that was in that bring to life what
other things happened really,

I think, are the incredible
learning that happens in these. And that's, again, the case and
the case method here at HBS.

So you knew about the case
method before you came. So I want to turn to
each of you and just say, was this method and
knowing about this method

important as you decided
whether to come here or not? You want to pick that up? OLLIE EVANS: Maybe I can start.

I think the case method
was a really big factor in my decision making. You know, I think
traditional school lectures,

so a lot of teachers
talking at you. And the exciting thing
about the case method was to get to learn from
not just the teacher

but also all of you
guys and my classmates. And so for me, getting
in and participating in a dynamic
environment and really

hear from people who had
experiences across industries and every country of
the world was something

that I was really excited about
and really was a major draw to come to HBS. BOB WHITE: OK, great. And you are right, Ollie,
because one of the key things

is you may have a
perspective, but there are other people in
the classroom that come from all sorts of
different perspectives.

And you thought that was
important as you chose. OLLIE EVANS: Absolutely. I think over the course of--

we've been, we're now
finishing our second year, we've probably all done over
500 cases at this point.

BOB WHITE: Could be,
close to 500 cases. OLLIE EVANS: And I just think-- SPEAKER 1: Wow. ISABEL KELLER: That's crazy. OLLIE EVANS: It's wild, you
know, when you look back on it.

But just having the
opportunity to then multiply that times the 90 people who
have the opportunity to speak,

you're almost to
5,000 perspectives that you could potentially
hear over two years. It's just an
incredible opportunity.

BOB WHITE: Great. ISABEL KELLER: I totally agree. It was really important
to me as well. And I think-- so I had
worked for six years

before coming to
business school. And something that was a
concern and that I really was looking for
when I came to visit

was, is sitting in a
classroom for two years going to feel like such a
departure from real life

been doing at work. And I remember I came to visit
a class when I was visiting,

and we were sitting in
this marketing class and they were trying to
decide if they should go with a B-to-B or a
B-to-C strategy for whatever

this product was. And the conversation
everyone had felt so similar to a
very similar conversation

I was having at work. And it kind of set off
this light bulb for me that because of the case method
and because of everybody kind

of bringing in their
experiences and the nature of the conversation, it did feel
very relevant and applicable

to real world settings. And it felt, just, it eased
my concern around feeling like sitting in a
classroom for two years

was going to feel
very different. BOB WHITE: When you
made the decision, you said this is going to
be an important part of why I want to come to
Harvard Business School.

Because you have that. You did, too, Ollie? SPEAKER 1: Yeah, I guess I have
a different perspective on it. I think it's--

I was so excited to come to HBS
for a lot of different reasons. The case method wasn't
really one I considered.

I probably should have. I think those are all
really great points. And now having gone
through two years, I think it's one of my
favorite parts of HBS.

And everyone watching, you
guys are a step ahead of me because you're watching this. BOB WHITE: Right. They're already
listening to this. SPEAKER 1: And I'm
already learning more

about the case method. But yeah, for me
it wasn't something I spent too much
time thinking about, but it's been one
of, if not the,

highlights of HBS. BOB WHITE: OK, great. All right. So we talk about what a case is.

We talk a little bit about
what the discussion is. So how do you prepare? How do you prepare for a case?

Anybody. Isabel, go ahead. ISABEL KELLER: I
think it's actually a really interesting mix
of the individual prep you

do on your own. So you'll sit and
you'll read the case and you'll take notes
and do whatever analysis you think you need to do and
come up with your own opinion.

And then what's really
awesome about the first year is you then have a
discussion group, which I'm sure we'll touch
on a little bit.

But just to give a quick
overview what that is, you basically are paired
with five other people from different sections.

It's a group of six. And you're required to
meet every single morning before class. And what it does is allows
you to kind of huddle up

with people before you then
have to go in and hopefully participate in
whatever the case is.

And I think it's a
really helpful way of helping you to test out
your thinking, to bring in other perspectives
into the conversation.

And it kind of brings
more of a group dynamic to prep beyond what
you do on your own. BOB WHITE: So on
average, how long

does it take to prepare a
case, the individual part? Give a range. SPEAKER 1: It totally depends.

ISABEL KELLER: I
think it depends. BOB WHITE: By the way, that's
always the right answer. In my class, I've always
told everyone, that's always the right answer, it depends.

But what is the range? Is it a half hour or is it
five hours, or is it an hour to an hour and a half each?

SPEAKER 1: I don't
think it's five hours. I'm sure some people
are spending-- ISABEL KELLER: I hope
it's not five hours.

BOB WHITE: It could
be an hour each? ISABEL KELLER: I think when
you're first starting out, it's probably closer to an hour
and a half, maybe two hours,

if you're being really thorough. But probably an hour. BOB WHITE: Because you're
going through again, as we described, to
try to figure out how to make the
decision because you're

going to be the person
making that decision. So it's an hour, hour and
a half, maybe two hours getting individual prepped.

Ollie, you agree with that? OLLIE EVANS: I think
what I'd say is, I mean, one of the beauties
of the HBS experience is learning how to prep
efficiently and really learning

how to be a critical thinker
and focusing on what matters. And so yes, your first
day at HBS, you know,

everyone does this case on
a cardiac hospital in India. People spend like two
hours or plus on that case.

But I think by your
last case, you'll rarely spend two hours on a case. You probably will
spend 30 or 45 minutes.

But your preparation
will probably be better at the end with
that shorter amount of time. And that's because you learn
how to focus on the key issues.

You learn how to ask for help. If you don't know how to
build a financial model or you don't know how to
lay out a marketing plan

and what pieces
matter, or you don't know how to think through
a leadership decision because you never
led anyone before, your classmates can
be really helpful.

And so you ask them
for their perspective. BOB WHITE: Good. And then that, quite
frankly, is getting better at that is like
business, getting better

at some of these
decisions and seeing business judgment and things. SPEAKER 1: Yeah. And I was going to add, it
sounds a bit like a chore

in like the hours it takes. But actually, it's really fun. Like I think some of the cases
I've spent the most time on,

it's not because they were so
hard that I couldn't get it and I was slaving
away and really upset.

It was it was because
I got into the problem and just kind of got
lost in it and was excited thinking through it.

Don't get me wrong,
there's certainly those cases that you
don't understand, even if you spend time with
the data going after it.

But some of the
most time I've spent is just because I
was purely interested and went in a lot of
different rabbit holes

that I didn't necessarily
need to, just wanted to. BOB WHITE: And then
once you do it prepared, you then said we have
these discussion groups.

And you said a couple
of things, Isabel, which is discussion
groups, individuals are from different sections. So just to be sure
everybody understands,

the first year you're
broken into sections where you stay with that
group the entire year.

Becomes part of the
family, if you will, right? But people are then assigned
to these discussion groups

across sections. And then you meet. And what goes on in one of
those study groups, Ollie? Is it a chance to try
your ideas, learn?

What happens with this? OLLIE EVANS: Yeah, I
think that the really-- curious to hear your feedback--
but the magical thing about the discussion
group is people

have really different
backgrounds. And so you know,
for me as someone who was an investor before, I've
at most led one other person.

And that direct report had the
exact same skill set I had. And so we could use
the same language. Whereas there was someone
in my discussion group

who had led a team in Iraq. And they had 50 people
who reported to them. And some of them could barely
read and others of them

were from top tier schools. And I think just having that
person give me perspective on how should I think
about a leadership problem

was incredibly helpful for me. And on the flip side,
when that person didn't know how to build
their financial model,

I could be helpful
to them to learn how to do the income statement. BOB WHITE: Great. And that's what
we're hoping for, right, we put a mix of
different backgrounds

but also different skills. So some of you might be
really strong in marketing can help those in that
group that are not strong.

But hopefully
someone in finance-- did that happen? Did you feel that was
going on in your group? SPEAKER 1: Yeah. I think it's very, it's very
humbling in that you find out

that there's so much
more you can learn. And it's really a
supportive environment. Like I think I was surprised.

I came in thinking that I didn't
have a background in accounting or finance. Those things can be
intimidating if you

don't know much about them. And I thought I would be the
person who was mooching off the group, like everybody
would be helping me

and I wouldn't be able to
contribute to the group. But instead, people
were excited to hear about my experiences
in other classes

that I had more experience in. And people were just really
kind with their time. Like I remember once
struggling with this model,

and the guy in my
discussion group was like, hey, let's meet
tomorrow 30 minutes

before our regular
scheduled time, which means he's getting
up earlier just to help me.

And I remember
commenting in that class and feeling really proud
that I'd cracked that.

And I remember telling him,
like, I wouldn't have been able to do this without you. BOB WHITE: Oh, great. SPEAKER 1: And I
don't think I would have guessed that people
would be so kind and generous

with their time. BOB WHITE: That's great. So we have a question
from the audience. One question is, what's
the most challenging case you've worked on at HBS?

Can you think of a
challenging case? ISABEL KELLER: There's one
kind of flagship Tom case.

BOB WHITE: When you
say Tom, what's Tom? ISABEL KELLER: Cranberry Tom
being technology and operations management.

And I don't know why. I guess it is very hard. It's very quantitative and
very kind of analytical.

And that's one that people
coming in seem to know about. And if you don't know about it,
you very quickly hear about it.

And I think that's an
interesting example of where people
really kind of lean into their discussion groups.
BOB WHITE: So how'd it work? So let's talk a little bit. So you had a challenging case. That's the classic one. How'd you get through it? It was challenging.

So how did you get
through the case? What did you learn from it? How'd it go? SPEAKER 1: I got a
lot of group texts.

ISABEL KELLER: Yeah. I mean, I think there,
again, to the point of in discussion groups and
just broadly in the section,

there are people that have
kind of very well defined skill sets. And I think this type of
case lends itself very well

to somebody who is
very logistics oriented and operationally oriented. And there are certainly people
here who are fabulous at that.

And I think I, at least,
leaned a lot on my classmates that I knew had that skill set. And I think, too, to the point
of leaning on people for help,

there's something
also about feeling like you're teaching
that I think is a valuable skill as well.

And so just knowing
how to do something. I think there's
something also to being able to articulate
it and coach someone

through it, which I feel very
grateful to the friends I had that were able to coach. But that was
definitely one where

you leaned on other people. BOB WHITE: And you
made it through it. You made it through it. ISABEL KELLER: We did
make it through it. That's the other thing, too,
as hard as they might be,

they're never as bad as you
think they're going to be. And you figure it out
and the class goes on. SPEAKER 1: And just
to build on that,

I think I had this perception
when I came in, or even before, that there was a right
answer, that you had to kind

of get it before you walked in. But if you think
about it, you're spending 80 minutes going
through the case in class.

If nothing in that
conversation surprises you, if you know everything
before you walk in,

you're probably spending
too much time on it. Like there's a
level here of, you need to feel like you have
an opinion, that you have

an idea that you kind of
have given it a good shot and worked together on it. But the point isn't
to get it perfect.

The point is to have an
opinion and change your mind and engage with it in class. BOB WHITE: Yeah. You just described a whole
bunch of stuff, which is, again,

having a point of
view, which you have, and a reason why you believe
that, but then being open minded. Because as Ollie said,
we have 90 students,

all from around the
world, different cultures, different backgrounds, and
different perspectives. And to be able to
be open minded is

that's what we hope to have
happen in these classes, that hopefully will maybe
not change your mind but give you a
different perspective.

It sounds like that's happened,
even in the challenging ones, too. We have another question. What's it like for someone
without a business background?

So what's it like for
people that are here without a business background? We all have worked here. Most-- what is it like?

OLLIE EVANS: Yeah. So I can speak from
the perspective. I have one of my really
close friends here who was a teacher for six
years before coming to HBS.

And I think for that
person, they definitely were very intimidated
coming to the environment and being in the classroom
with a lot of other people

who had maybe more traditional
business backgrounds. But then on the first
day, that person realized that the person
sitting next to them

had been a professional
athlete for seven years before coming HBS. And it was funny, because
they were like, well,

I guess I'm more prepared
than a professional athlete because I had to at least dress
up and go to work every day.

[LAUGHTER] And so I think that's one
of the things about HBS that you realize is
that you're never

going to be the best at anything
here because there's always someone who's world class. But you're also not
going to be the worst. And we're all kind
of in this together.

And so I think for
me and that person, like, yeah, I had to
help that person out with maybe finance or some
of the more different topics

they hadn't experienced before. But then at the same time,

how education works in the US

and why so many people don't

seat here contributes so much

and it's just an incredibly
humbling experience, regardless of your background. BOB WHITE: That's great. SPEAKER 1: And just to--

with those backgrounds have so much to contribute

a little perspective from the faculty perspective

thought into each case, where it is in the class, where
it is in the curriculum,

why is that case in there. We have certain teaching
objectives for every case. And it's in, again, in that
curriculum at that point
in time for a certain reason. You have your discussion groups. We have teaching groups.

we will have met as a faculty and talked about what the
progression we hope to get,

as well as what the
teaching objectives are. So we are working doing
